title: Erdős Problem #1032: 4-Chromatic Critical Graphs with High Minimum Degree
description: Do there exist 4-chromatic critical graphs on n vertices with minimum degree linear in n?

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this question over 20 years before 1993. Dirac constructed 6-chromatic critical graphs with δ > n/2, and Simonovits–Toft achieved δ ≫ n^{1/3} for 4-chromatic critical graphs. The gap between n^{1/3} and linear remains open. Toft conjectured that 4-chromatic critical graphs have ≥ (5/3+o(1))n edges.
overview.problemStatement: Do there exist 4-chromatic critical graphs on n vertices with minimum degree ≫ n?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization axiomatises graph properties (vertex count, min degree, chromatic number, edges) and k-chromatic criticality. Known constructions and Toft's edge conjecture are stated. The main conjecture asks for linear minimum degree.
keyInsights: k-chromatic critical: χ = k and every edge removal reduces χ
The gap between n^{1/3} and n is wide; linear δ is the target

sections.title: Graph Properties
sections.summary: Axiomatised vertex count, min degree, chromatic number, edges, and k-chromatic criticality.

sections.title: Known Constructions
sections.summary: Dirac (6-chromatic, δ > n/2) and Simonovits–Toft (4-chromatic, δ ≫ n^{1/3}).

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: 4-chromatic critical graphs with linear minimum degree exist. Extended to k = 5.

conclusion.summary: The formalization captures Erdős Problem 1032, asking whether 4-chromatic critical graphs with linear minimum degree exist.
conclusion.implications: A positive answer would show that critical graphs can be highly connected, bridging the gap between Simonovits–Toft's n^{1/3} and Dirac's linear bound for higher chromatic numbers.
openQuestions: Do 4-chromatic critical graphs with δ ≫ n exist?
